Award.AwardTitle: Bacterial Photosynthetic Design Probed by Multidimensional Spectroscopies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Photosynthetic organisms employ elaborate antenna arrays to harvest solar energy and transfer it to reaction centers with ~95% efficiency. At the heart of this stunning efficiency is the energy landscape that provides directional ultrafast transfer of energy between the antennae and reaction centers, and directional charge separation within reaction centers. Recently two-dimensional electronic spectroscopy (2DES) has emerged as a powerful method for studying energy transfer and charge separation in photosynthesis. 2DES and other spectroscopic measurements have suggested that key electronic-vibrational dynamics may enhance photosynthetic efficiency. The proposed work will enhance the experimental tools for studying energy transfer and charge separation in natural and artificial systems. The extensive experimental characterization of bacterial photosystems will drive the development of theoretical models of the electronic structure and dynamics of multichromophoric assemblies. The understanding gained from purple bacteria as a model system will inform our understanding of the more complex plant photosystems and may guide the design of artificial light-harvesting materials. The proposed work will provide extensive scientific training for graduate and undergraduate students and will also support a wide range of outreach activities. These include the organization and participation in the APS Conferences for Undergraduate Women in Physics (CUWiPs). These meetings bring together undergraduate women from the across the country, educating them about career opportunities and state-of-the-art research in Physics, thereby strengthening the network of women in Physics in the US. The proposal aims to foster a love of physics among children from diverse age groups and backgrounds through participation in the yearly Physics Olympiad and science exploration days for Girl Scouts troops.

This project aims to push the frontiers of multidimensional spectroscopy to address the following open questions about bacterial photosynthesis: i) Do key protein or cofactor dynamics enhance energy transfer and charge separation in purple bacteria? ii) How do purple bacteria remodel their energy-landscape to regulate energy transfer under high and low light conditions? To address question i) bacterial reaction centers will be studied in unprecedented detail with a palette of electronic and vibrational multidimensional spectroscopies, providing a dynamical picture of the pigments and surrounding protein during charge separation. Moving beyond studies of the isolated components to address question ii) 2DES of whole cells will be used to map the complete energy transfer and charge separation pathways of purple bacteria: from the visible to near-infrared wavelengths with ultrafast time resolution. The rich spectroscopic data to be obtained in the proposed experiments will provide critical feedback to theoretical modeling of energy transfer and charge separation in purple bacteria.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photosynthetic organisms employ an elaborate architecture of antenna arrays to gather solar energy and transfer it to photochemical reaction centers for conversion to stable charge separation. The processes of photosynthetic energy transfer and charge separation occur with near unit quantum efficiency. Underlying this stunning efficiency is the energy landscape that provides ultrafast directional transfer of energy from antennae to reaction centers, and directional electron transfer within reaction centers. Understanding the design principles of natural photosynthesis could enable us to design the next generation of artificial light-harvesting materials. This project supported research to develop the capabilities of multidimensional spectroscopy as a powerful and quantitative method, and bring the new spectroscopic tools to bear on open questions about photosynthesis in purple bacteria. Specifically, the project aimed to understand whether key protein or cofactor dynamics enhance energy transfer and charge separation in purple bacteria and to uncover the electronic structure and charge separation mechanism of the bacterial reaction center (BRC). By expanding the spectroscopic toolset and extensively characterizing BRCs we aim to provide feedback to theoretical modeling of energy transfer and charge separation. We also aim to ultimately pave the way for a better understanding of plant photosystems. Such an understanding is a fundamental pursuit that will enable us to learn from Nature to meet our own energy needs through the development of artificial light-harvesting systems and biofuels.

Two-dimensional electronic spectroscopy (2DES) has proven to be a powerful tool for studying photosynthetic energy transfer and charge separation. With ultrafast time resolution, it reveals coupling between the components of photosynthetic systems, allowing the elucidation of energy transfer pathways and mechanisms. Previous 2DES studies of photosynthetic antennae complexes revealed puzzling long-lived coherent dynamics. The physical origin and possible functional relevance of these coherences have been hotly debated. Through this project we performed the first 2DES studies of charge separation in the bacterial reaction center (BRC). We developed a new global analysis technique for uncovering complex kinetics from 2DES data. This method extends approaches used previously in lower dimensional time-resolved spectroscopies to include the additional exciton frequency dimension available with 2DES. We used the method to test different models of charge separation in the BRC, finding that our data supports a model in which rapid energy equilibration in the BRC is followed by charge separation via a single pathway. Our data definitively revealed a previously hidden excitonic state and provided a detailed excitonic model of the BRC. We also observed coherent dynamics in the BRC, as well as in monomer photosynthetic pigments and determined the physical origin of the coherent dynamics. These studies provided important benchmarks for determining the physical origin of coherence and revealed the importance of the interaction between vibrational and electronic degrees of freedom in mediating energy transfer and charge separation in the BRC.

The broader impacts of this project include enhancing our experimental and theoretical tools for understanding energy transfer and charge separation in natural and artificial systems. Our measurements provide new data that can guide the improvement of theoretical modeling of energy transfer and charge separation in bacterial photosystems, ultimately paving the way for a better understanding of plant photosystems and artificial light-harvesting materials.  

This project supported the extensive training of graduate and undergraduate students, teaching them a wide range of skills, from the design of optical experiments, the hardware interfacing required for data acquisition, to data-taking, analysis and modeling, and scientific communication. The project also supported the PI in yearly coaching of elementary school teams for the Washtenaw Science Olympiad. The PI and her group have been active in other outreach activities, including lab tours to economically disadvantaged students, a day of science for K-6 Girl Scouts and Physics Demo Day at a local middle school.
